title: Broadway Cancels Some Performances as New York City's Covid-19 Cases Rise; Performances of 'Tina—The Tina Turner Musical', 'Hamilton' and 'Mrs. Doubtfire' were canceled in recent days
text:
Broadway's plans are just the latest to be upended amid the latest bout of uncertainty over the pandemic. Covid-19 cases and hospitalizations are on the rise even as the percentage of U.S. residents who are vaccinated continues to increase. And the percentage of Covid-19 cases in the U.S. caused by the rapidly moving Omicron variant is rising as well.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said Thursday that the city would be increasing its testing capacity and would distribute one million KN95 masks. He said the city will also give out half a million at-home rapid tests and will start a media campaign to encourage people to get Covid-19 booster shots.

The city will also focus on inspecting businesses to ensure they are following Covid-19 mandates, he said.

"It is clear that the Omicron variant is here in New York City in full force," Mr. de Blasio said, who noted that Covid-19 cases have risen substantially over the past few days.

New York Gov. Kathy Hochul recently announced that people must wear masks indoors unless it was required by a venue or business that they be vaccinated. The policy is in effect until Jan. 15 and the state will re-evaluate it after that.

The majority of Broadway shows reopened in September after many had been closed since March 2020—a blow to the industry and New York's economy. Before the pandemic, shows during the 2018-19 season sold more than 14 million tickets and grossed $1.8 billion over a record 1,737 performances, according to the Broadway League trade group.

Rising Covid-19 case counts have prompted some colleges and universities, including Princeton University and Cornell University, to shift their end-of-year plans and make exams remote or allow students to finish their semester online. Various professional sports teams have also experienced Covid-19 outbreaks and had to recently cancel games. Some companies, including Apple Inc., have shifted their return-to-office dates.
